content: The Act may be cited as the "Raise And Index to Sustainably and Efficiently Invest in Transportation Act of 2017" or the "RAISE IT Act". Since SAFETEA-LU, over $140 billion has been transferred from the General Fund to the Highway Trust Fund to maintain solvency. The Congressional Budget Office predicts annual transfers of over $20 billion will be needed post-FY 2021. The American Society for Civil Engineers suggests an additional $1.1 trillion investment in the transportation system by 2025. The Simpson-Bowles plan recommends a fifteen-cent gas tax increase. Bowles' plan recommends raising the gas tax by fifteen cents, aligning with the National Surface Transportation Infrastructure Financing Commission's suggestion to prevent the Highway Trust Fund insolvency. Nine states raised gas taxes for transportation revenue in 2015-2016. Congress aims to replace the gas tax with a more sustainable funding source by 2027. The plan suggests increasing the gas tax by fifteen cents to prevent the Highway Trust Fund insolvency. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel. Gasoline tax rates are set at 18.3 cents per gallon before 2018, 26.3 cents per gallon in 2018, 30.3 cents per gallon in 2019, and 33.3 cents per gallon after 2019 but before 2030. Diesel fuel and kerosene taxes are also adjusted accordingly. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase taxes on diesel fuel and kerosene. The tax rates are set at 24.3 cents per gallon before 2018, 32.3 cents per gallon in 2018, 36.3 cents per gallon in 2019, and 39.3 cents per gallon after 2019 but before 2029. Additionally, there is an adjustment for inflation in tax rates starting from 2020. The tax rates on diesel fuel and kerosene are increased annually after 2019 based on the cost of living adjustment. The rate for diesel-water fuel emulsion is amended to 71 percent of the original rate. The tax rates on diesel fuel and kerosene increase annually after 2019 based on the cost of living adjustment. The rate for diesel-water fuel emulsion is amended to 71 percent of the original rate, with termination set for December 31, 2028. Allocation in accounts in the Highway Trust Fund is also adjusted. The tax rates on diesel fuel and kerosene increase annually after 2019 based on the cost of living adjustment. The rate for diesel-water fuel emulsion is amended to 71 percent of the original rate, with termination set for December 31, 2028. Allocation in accounts in the Highway Trust Fund is also adjusted. In addition, there is an adjustment for inflation in the tax rate for calendar years after 2019. The amendments made by this section apply to fuels or liquids removed, entered, or sold after December 31, 2017, with any increase rounded to the nearest 0.1 cents. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be due under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code over the tax already paid. Liability and Payment: The person holding the liquid is responsible for the tax, to be paid as prescribed by the Secretary within 6 months of the floor stocks tax date. The floor stocks tax date is defined as any January 1 after a tax rate increase under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The term "taxable liquid" refers to diesel fuel and kerosene, excluding aviation-grade kerosene. The Secretary of the Treasury is referred to as the "Secretary." The floor stocks tax date applies to taxable liquid held for certain uses, with exceptions for liquid held in vehicle tanks and limited amounts of liquid held on the tax date. Exempt fuel and controlled groups are defined for tax purposes, with exemptions for fuel not subject to tax and treating controlled groups as a single entity. Under regulations prescribed by the Secretary, principles similar to those for corporations shall apply to a group of persons under common control. All provisions of law applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 of the Code shall also apply to floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a).
